<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 302, 314]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Theory (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 338, 415, 354]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 368, 374]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 715, 432]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 320, 446]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 446, 504, 461]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 460, 504, 475]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 475, 384, 490]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 501, 255, 515]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 515, 359, 530]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 530, 767, 560]]<|/det|>
You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 604, 585]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 584, 759, 600]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A rocket is stationary on the launchpad. At time \(t = 0\), the rocket engines are switched on and exhaust gases are ejected from the nozzles of the engines. The rocket accelerates upwards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 118, 856, 137]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows how the acceleration of the rocket varies between time \(t = 0\) and time \(t = t_{\mathrm{f}}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 145, 809, 378]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 399, 534, 417]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 431, 146, 450]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 431, 324, 450]]<|/det|>
Define acceleration.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 491, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 522, 148, 541]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 522, 920, 556]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 1.2, sketch a graph to show how the speed of the rocket varies between time \(t = 0\) and time \(t = t_{\mathrm{f}}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 562, 781, 800]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 821, 534, 839]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 833, 920, 852]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
Some time later, the rocket is far from the Earth. The effect of the Earth's gravity on the motion of the rocket is insignificant. As the rocket accelerates, its momentum increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 181, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 117, 631, 135]]<|/det|>
State the principle of the conservation of momentum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 210, 920, 228]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 240, 181, 259]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 240, 920, 274]]<|/det|>
Explain how the principle of the conservation of momentum applies to the accelerating rocket and the exhaust gases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 380, 920, 399]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 412, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 504, 89]]<|/det|>
Fig. 2.1 shows a sign that extends over a road.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 101, 816, 448]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 469, 532, 488]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 500, 420, 518]]<|/det|>
The mass of the sign is \(3.4 \times 10^{3} \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 549, 146, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 548, 445, 567]]<|/det|>
Calculate the weight \(W\) of the sign.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 609, 922, 626]]<|/det|>
<form>W = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 640, 146, 658]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 640, 920, 673]]<|/det|>
The weight of the sign acts at a horizontal distance of \(1.8 \text{m}\) from the centre of the support post and it produces a turning effect about point P.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 686, 774, 703]]<|/det|>
Point P is a horizontal distance of \(1.3 \text{m}\) from the centre of the support post.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 718, 181, 736]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 718, 688, 736]]<|/det|>
Calculate the moment about P due to the weight of the sign.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 867, 920, 885]]<|/det|>
<form>moment = .................................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A concrete block is positioned on the other side of the support post with its centre of mass a horizontal distance of \(70 \text{cm}\) from the centre of the support post.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 117, 222, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>1.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 117, 556, 135]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by centre of mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 180, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 210, 217, 228]]<|/det|>
<label>2.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 210, 920, 243]]<|/det|>
The weight of the concrete block produces a moment about point P that exactly cancels the moment caused by the weight \(W.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 256, 584, 274]]<|/det|>
Calculate the weight of the concrete block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[510, 371, 920, 390]]<|/det|>
<form>weight = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 403, 144, 422]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 403, 920, 437]]<|/det|>
The concrete block is removed. The sign and support post rotate about point P in a clockwise direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 450, 920, 483]]<|/det|>
State and explain what happens to the moment about point P due to the weight of the sign as it rotates.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 586, 922, 604]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A cube of side \(0.040 \text{m}\) is floating in a container of liquid. Fig. 3.1 shows that the surface of the liquid is \(0.028 \text{m}\) above the level of the bottom face of the cube.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 112, 853, 316]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 335, 532, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 365, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
The pressure of the air above the cube exerts a force on the top face of the cube. The valve is closed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 425, 144, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 425, 902, 444]]<|/det|>
Explain, in terms of air molecules, how the force due to the pressure of the air is produced.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 572, 146, 591]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 572, 613, 591]]<|/det|>
The density of the liquid in the container is \(1500 \text{kg} /\text{m}^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 603, 243, 621]]<|/det|>
Calculate:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 634, 180, 652]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 634, 616, 652]]<|/det|>
the pressure due to the liquid at a depth of 0.028 m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[490, 765, 920, 784]]<|/det|>
<form>pressure = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 795, 180, 814]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 795, 865, 814]]<|/det|>
the force on the bottom face of the cube caused by the pressure due to the liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[522, 912, 920, 931]]<|/det|>
<form>force = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 912, 920, 931]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
The valve is opened and liquid is pumped into the container. The surface of the liquid rises a distance of \(0.034 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 918, 151]]<|/det|>
The cube remains floating in the liquid with its bottom face \(0.028 \text{m}\) below the surface of the liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 181, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 164, 675, 183]]<|/det|>
Calculate the work done on the cube by the force in **(b)**(ii).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 265, 920, 282]]<|/det|>
<form>work done = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 295, 181, 314]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 295, 828, 314]]<|/det|>
Suggest one reason why this is not an efficient method of lifting up the cube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 365, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 389, 920, 408]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Gas of mass \(0.23 \text{g}\) is trapped in a cylinder by a piston. The gas is at atmospheric pressure which is \(1.0 \times 10^{5} \text{Pa}\). Fig. 4.1 shows the piston held in position by a catch.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 116, 765, 299]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 312, 532, 330]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 343, 510, 362]]<|/det|>
The volume of the trapped gas is \(1.9 \times 10^{-4} \text{m}^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 374, 819, 393]]<|/det|>
An electrical heater is used to increase the temperature of the trapped gas by \(550^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 421, 144, 440]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 420, 591, 440]]<|/det|>
The specific heat capacity of the gas is \(0.72 \text{J} / (\text{g} \degree \text{C})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 452, 180, 471]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 451, 915, 471]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[505, 560, 920, 580]]<|/det|>
<form>energy = ....................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 591, 180, 610]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 591, 468, 610]]<|/det|>
The power of the heater is \(2.4 \text{W}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 623, 905, 643]]<|/det|>
1. Calculate how long it takes for the heater to supply the energy calculated in **(a)**(i).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 732, 920, 752]]<|/det|>
<form>time = ......................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 765, 220, 784]]<|/det|>
<label>2.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 764, 920, 798]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 810, 470, 829]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 845, 920, 864]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 887, 920, 907]]<|/det|>

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 920, 121]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Green light of frequency \(5.7 \times 10^{14} \text{Hz}\) is travelling in air at a speed of \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\). The light is incident on the surface of a transparent solid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 752, 135]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 836, 91]]<|/det|>
A student turns the handle of an alternating current (a.c.) generator and the coil rotates.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 559, 121]]<|/det|>
